channel.title: Mastodon Home Timeline
channel.description: RSS feed for the Mastodon Home timeline

item.title: Boris Barbour
item.description: So this New Y√∂rker article has a few very interesting items.1) A French woman driven out of academia, called Zoe Ziani, was instrumental in setting Data Colada onto both Gino and Ariely. All credit to her.2) The author got a file sent by the Hartford insurance company to Ariely, and it's nothing like the purported original data!3) The Duke investigation into Ariely has barely passed the triage stage. Is it possible to go more slowly?https://www.newyorker.com/magazine/2023/10/09/they-studied-dishonesty-was-their-work-a-lie

item.title: Manlio De Domenico
item.description:
Even if public Health is not caring that much nowadays, this result is relevant:
"In a highly immune adult population, median SARS-CoV-2 viral loads peaked around the fourth day of symptoms" https://academic.oup.com/cid/advance-article/doi/10.1093/cid/ciad582/7285011

item.title: Dorothy Bishop
item.description:
thread summarising yesterday's blogpost, re fraudulent articles from papermills. https://deevybee.blogspot.com/2023/10/spitting-out-ai-gobbledegook-sandwich.html
There has been a scandal at the publisher Hindawi that led to retraction of 1000s of papers.
In the past there was little motivation for publishers to act on such fraud, as they made a healthy profit from all articles, regardless of quality, & they'd accordingly expanded their operations massively, mainly through "special issues" with guest editors.

item.title: Konrad Kording
item.description: For all the folks hoping for optogenetics for chemistry Nobel: whom would you give it to? The folks who made the idea? Who found the molecules? Or the people who popularized them? The Nobel prize is no longer meaningful in the era of large collaborations and specialization.

item.title: addie
item.description: Continues to age like fine wine, like 15 years later

item.title: Kim Scheinberg
item.description:
@mekkaokereke
She knew how to take a parting shot:That morning at the lab, Kariko‚Äôs old boss had come to see her off. She did not tell him what a terrible mistake he was making in letting her leave. She didn‚Äôt gloat about her future at BioNTech [...] then a relative upstart in the field. Instead the woman who had bounced from dep't to dep't, with no tenure prospects and never earning over $60,000 a year, said with total confidence: ‚ÄúIn the future, this lab will be a museum. Don‚Äôt touch it.‚Äù

item.title: Joanne Fisher
item.description: ‚ÄúThe trouble is that we have a bad habit, encouraged by pedants and sophisticates, of considering happiness as something rather stupid. Only pain is intellectual, only evil interesting. This is the treason of the artist: a refusal to admit the banality of evil and the terrible boredom of pain.‚Äù ‚Äî¬† Ursula K. Le GuinFrom the story The Ones Who Walk Away From Omelas. #ursulakleguin #quote

item.title: Konrad Kording
item.description: @manlius @PessoaBrain @tiago @lmrocha @thilo @NicoleCRust @hirokisayama @WiringtheBrain Add teleology and things are easier no? A forest fire used by humans on purpose to move air may well be a machine in common language.

item.title: Fabrizio Musacchio
item.description: New book by Wei Ji Ma, @kordinglab and Daniel Goldreich: ‚Äú#Bayesian Models of #Perception and Action ‚Äì An Introduction‚Äù. ‚ÄúAn accessible introduction to constructing and interpreting Bayesian models of perceptual #DecisionMaking and action.‚Äùüåè https://mitpress.mit.edu/9780262372824/bayesian-models-of-perception-and-action/#CompNeuro #ComputationalNeuroscience

item.title: @AllenNeuroLab
item.description: @kordinglab I was kinda hoping that someone would win the Nobel Prize for contextual fear conditioning since it‚Äôs taught us as much about the brain than anything else in the last few decades. So I‚Äôd go with Michael Fanselow.

item.title: Dan Goodman
item.description: @kordinglab I think I'd do the work for every paper I ever wrote differently, including the ones I'm writing up now. üòâ

item.title: Carl Zimmer
item.description: Today I wrote about a new study on same-sex sexual behavior in mammals. It's evolved often, and looks like an adaptation to social living. Here's the story [gift link] https://tinyurl.com/ysj5wbzk

item.title: Benjamin Geer
item.description: @NicoleCRust She has some suggestions here: https://www.aargauerzeitung.ch/leben/interview-top-scientist-katalin-kariko-women-should-have-a-career-and-a-happy-family-ld.2352504

item.title: Sarah Taber
item.description: New Farm to Taber episode! @pluralistic joins in to talk about taking on systems that are way bigger than us. Extremely relevant for both the tech & food spaces!Includes bonus photo edit: Cor(n)y Doctorowhttps://shows.acast.com/farm-to-taber/episodes/diy-isnt-enough-systematic-change-with-cory-doctorow

item.title: Richard Sever
item.description: The past, present and future of science publishing. Long read from me giving the history (not always told well), details of how journals actually work (useful for young scientists and to clarify for old hands), and discussion of how the future could look in a post-preprint world (spoiler: academia could get this wrong). https://journals.plos.org/plosbiology/article?id=10.1371/journal.pbio.3002234

item.title: Earl K. Miller
item.description: I've received my copy of 'Charlie's Lab,' an unconventional biography about a unique place.

item.title: Chris Chambers
item.description: Delighted that @siminevazire has been appointed as the next Editor-in-Chief of Psychological Science. This is a big step forward for the transparency and reproducibility of our field.Thank you to everyone who supported my bid.https://www.psychologicalscience.org/publications/ps-incoming-eic-2024

item.title: mekka okereke :verified:
item.description: Really good paper by Dr. Emerson Murphy-Hill and friends, about what the Engineers and Managers at Google that have successfully built and sustained inclusive teams, found worked for them.‚ô•Ô∏èüëçüèøhttps://research.google/pubs/pub52616/(Related: I love my little hot takes and tweets about inclusion and all, but nothing beats sound, rigorous research to back up all the vibes and typos. Dr. Murphy-Hill is one of the folks that consistently produces good work that makes the whole industry better. Read his stuff.)
